The Program Loan   
   
Rationale  The Country Strategy for Bangladesh of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) aims to reduce poverty, by among others, promoting 
faster  private  sector-led  economic  growth  by  accelerating  the 
pace  of  structured  reforms  and  providing  assistance  for 
improvement in infrastructure. The Sector Development Program 
supports  the  Government’s  ongoing  Power  Sector  Reforms  in 
Bangladesh (PSRB) adopted in 1994 to (i) improve governance, 
(ii) build long-term institutional capacity, (iii) improve efficiency and 
financial  viability,  and  (iv) facilitate  private  sector  participation. 
Since 1994, the Government has, with the support of ADB and 
other  development  partners,  carried  out  the  following  major 
actions under its reform program: 
•  introduction of private sector participation in generation; 
•  creation of five new companies in generation, transmission, 
and distribution; 
•  restructuring of the distribution areas; 
•  reduction  of  system  losses  by  computerized  billing  and 
improved collection management; and 
•  Parliament’s  passage  of  the  new  Energy  Act  2003  as  a 
foundation  for  the  establishment  of  an  Energy  Regulatory 
Commission (ERC). 
This phase of the reforms involves financial stabilization of the 
sector  entities  created  earlier  under  the  reform  program  and 
corporatization of another four sector entities, to enable improved 
governance  through  regulatory  oversight,  and  to  introduce 
structured competition and discipline in the sector. 
 
Objective  The objective of the Sector Development Program is to support 
the Government’s efforts to reform the power sector through the 
financial stabilization of two major transmission and distribution 
companies, Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB) and 
Dhaka  Electric  Supply  Company  (DESCO),  and  partially 
Bangladesh  Power  Development  Board  (BPDB)  and  Dhaka 
Electric Supply Authority (DESA) by settlement of outstanding 
dues  of  the  Government,  and  its  semi-autonomous  and 
autonomous bodies to the sector. These actions will prepare the 
sector for long-term financial sustainability and gradually relieve 
the Government of financial support for the sector.

The Project Loan   
 
Project Description  The project loan has three components: 
 
Part A: Construction of 2 x 100-megawatt (MW) peaking power 
generation capacity at Siddhirganj near Dhaka. 
 
Part  B:  Construction  of  a  national  load  dispatch  center  at 
Rampura in Dhaka. 
 
Part C: Renovation, upgrading, and extension of distribution in 
Rajshahi, Serajgonj, Bogra, Pabna, Rangpur, Dinajpur, Joypurhat, 
Thakurgaon,  Nilphamari,  and  Gaibanda  towns  in  northwest 
Bangladesh. 
   
Rationale  The power system of Bangladesh is still suffering from: (i) load 
shedding due to lack of peak load capacity during peak hours 
(twice as high as the base load demand); (ii) lack of facilities for 
efficient  competitive  dispatch  of  the  power  generation;  and 
(iii) insufficient and unreliable supply of electricity in urban and 
rural areas outside Dhaka. In improving governance and financial 
performance some of sector entities have already been set up as 
independent  companies  although  still  financially  suffering  from 
earlier weak management. A joint intervention of investment in 
generation  peak  load  capacity,  load  dispatch  facilities,  and 
upgraded  distribution  system  simultaneously  with  further 
unbundling and corporatization of additional power sector entities, 
and  financial  support  through  settlement  of  the  Government’s 
outstanding  dues  will  have  a  major  long-term  impact  on 
performance and financial viability of the sector. 
   
Objectives  The objective of the Project is to improve the quality of electricity 
supply by (i) improving peak load generation capacity to reduce 
load  shedding,  (ii) introducing  competition  in  generation  by 
investment  in  a  new  National  Load  Dispatch  Center  (NLDC), 
(iii) improving  network  reliability,  and  (iv) increasing  access  to 
electricity  services  by  upgrading  and  new  investments  in  ten 
towns in the northwest of Bangladesh. This support will further 
boost the restructuring of the sector by transferring the operation 
of the urban distribution in northwest Bangladesh from BPDB to 
North-west Zone Power Distribution Company (being created) and 
improve  losses  and  extension  of  electricity  supply  to  urban 
households and the commercial sector. This will also improve the 
supply situation in rural areas under PBSs that are getting power 
through  medium-voltage  networks  of  some  urban  distribution 
systems under the Project. 
   
Cost Estimates  The  Project  is  estimated  to  cost  $328.5 million  equivalent, 
comprising  $195.6 million  in  foreign  exchange  costs  and 
$132.9 million in local currency costs.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on two proposed 
loans to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Power Sector Development Program and 
the Power Sector Development Project. 
 
II.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  The power sector in Bangladesh performed poorly through the late 1980s and 1990s. 
The major constraints in the sector were (i) lack of institutional capability; (ii) unavailability of 
long-term domestic capital for financing investments; (iii) limited foreign exchange debt service 
capability of the economy; (iv) poor management systems and procedures; (v) low employee 
commitment; and (vi) institutional weaknesses in governance, banking, law enforcement, and 
judicial processes, which are external to the sector but are essential for its proper functioning. 
 
3.  In 1994, the Government of Bangladesh adopted a paper titled Power Sector Reforms in 
Bangladesh (PSRB), which was formulated in consultation with the major development partners 
(DPs)1 in the power sector. The PSRB outlined the reform process proposed to be followed by 
the Government to gradually remove the constraints in the sector through improvements in 
sector and corporate governance, introduction of competition, and public-private partnerships. 
Reform of the external environment was to be done through targeted interventions in the power 
sector. Sector and subsector analysis is further presented in Appendix 1. 
 
4.  Bangladesh’s annual per capita electricity consumption of 110 kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 
FY2003 was the third lowest among the developing member countries of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), after Cambodia and Nepal.2 Despite intensive efforts to increase coverage, only 
about 32% of the population has access to electricity.3 Consumption of electricity in Bangladesh 
grew at an average annual rate of 8.2% from FY1994 to FY2002, with major increases in 
industrial and residential use. The Power System Master Plan Study financed by ADB4 estimated 
that the demand for electricity would increase by about 8% per year for the following 10 years, 
which has been the actual growth. The current installed capacity is 4,710 megawatts (MW). The 
peak demand met was 3,622 MW on 17 August 2003.  
 
5.  Inadequate supply of electricity is a major constraint to economic growth. During FY2003, 
load shedding in the range of 5–468 MW was resorted to on 210 days for a total duration of 767 
hours. The situation has improved since November 2002 with (i) elimination of gas supply 
constraints to power stations, (ii) full commissioning of the 360 MW Haripur independent power 
producer (IPP) station, (iii) full commissioning of the 450 MW Meghnaghat-1 IPP station and 
100 MW expansion in Baghabari, and (iv) reinforcement of the Dhaka 230-kilovolt (kV) grid and 
completion of the Rampura 230 kV substation. Some load shedding is expected to continue until 
substantial new generation capacity is added to the system to (i) replace  very  old  power 
stations, (ii) allow for routine preventive maintenance through creation of reserve margin, and

B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Government Policies and Plans 
6.  The  PSRB  envisions,  in  the  long-term,  a  structure  of  the  power  sector  based  on 
(i) separation of sector regulation and operation; (ii) autonomy and commercial orientation of the 
sector entities; (iii) separation of generation, transmission, and distribution; and (iv) increased 
private  sector  participation.  Under  such  a  structure,  a  new  regulatory  authority  would  be 
responsible  for  (i) setting  electricity  tariffs  and  determining  the  corresponding  performance 
norms; (ii) collecting, verifying, and disseminating sector statistics; (iii) reviewing and approving 
long-term power planning; (iv) creating and maintaining a nondiscriminatory and commercial 
business environment in the sector; and (v) adjudicating disputes between sector entities. While 
transmission will remain in the public sector, generation and distribution assets will have both 
public and private ownership. The objective is to eliminate monopolies and foster competition. 
Commercial  discipline  and  good  customer  service  are  expected  to  be  achieved  through 
competition among entities in the power sector.  
 
7.  With the initiation of reforms in 1994, the organizational setup of the sector has changed. 
Whereas in 1994, all generation was with BPDB, today there are several public/private and 
private sector entities that have been licensed to construct and operate power-generating 
facilities. The first private barge-mounted power station started operation in December 1998. 
The first gas turbine of the Rural Power Company (RPC) at its Mymensingh site5 started 
operation in April 2000 and now has a capacity of 140 MW; construction of a 70 MW steam 
turbine portion is in progress to convert the plant to combined-cycle operation. Three barge-
mounted power stations totaling about 310 MW are  operating, as are, since June 2002, the 
combined-cycle plant of the Haripur (360 MW) IPP station, the Meghnaghat-1 (450 MW) IPP 
station,6 and the 100 MW expansion at Baghabari. IPPs now account for about 40% of net 
power generation in the country. 
 
8.  As a direct result of assistance by ADB and Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW), five 
new companies have been established— Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB), Dhaka 
Electric Supply Company (DESCO), RPC, Ashuganj Power Company, and West Zone Power 
Distribution Company. While RPC was a new start-up generation company, PGCB took over 
assets and liabilities of the existing transmission operations of BPDB and DESA, while Ashuganj 
Power Company and West Zone Power Distribution Company took over assets and liabilities of 
the existing operations of BPDB. DESCO was created based on a transfer of assets and 
liabilities  of  the  Mirpur—later  expanded  to  cover  the  erstwhile  Gulshan  circle—distribution

10.  Good governance, at both the sector and the corporate levels, is emphasized in the 
PSRB.  At  the  sector  level,  governance  is  to  be  improved  through  predictability  (long-term 
planning,  codification  of  rules  and  regulations,  and  independence  of  regulatory  processes), 
transparency  (systematic  dissemination  of  relevant  sector  information,  public  hearings,  and 
discussions on issues before they are decided), and accountability (cause-effect structure of 
incentives).  At  the  corporate  level,  governance  is  being  enhanced  through  corporatization, 
independence of the boards of directors from the Government, introduction of work-based pay 
structure, defined delegation of powers to staff, computerized management information systems, 
and commercialization of activities. 
 
11.  With regard to the Government’s dues to BPDB, Rural Electrification Board (REB), and 
DESA, it is imperative for the Government to lead in commercializing the sector by liquidating 
the arrears owed by it and its agencies to BPDB, DESA, DESCO, and the palli bidyut samity 
(rural electric cooperatives, or PBSs). In September 2001, the Government made a special 
budget allocation of Tk690 million (about 30% of  its total dues) to settle outstanding dues to 
BPDB and DESA. This process will be continued and expanded under the Program to include 
DESCO and PBSs, along with a comprehensive financial restructuring of the sector, initially 
focused on PGCB and DESCO. 
 
12.  The Government has agreed to compensate DESCO for losses incurred during the initial 
period of operations. DESCO assumed charge of the loss-incurring Mirpur area from DESA in 
September 1998. At that time, the collection-to-import ratio of Mirpur was  35%. With great 
perseverance, DESCO has improved the operations in Mirpur and the collection-to-import ratio

3.  Lessons Learned 
19.  ADB has been extensively supporting the power sector over the last 25 years. From being 
a provider of funds for individual projects in the 1970s, it became a provider of funds as well as 
technical advice in the 1980s. Since the adoption of the PSRB in 1994, ADB has been providing 
policy advice to the Government in implementing the PSRB, as well as funds to help achieve the 
least-cost expansion program. During this involvement, ADB has learned the lessons outlined in 
the following paragraphs.  
 
20.  The key lessons identified from two project performance audit reports8 (PPARs) included 
(i) need for more rigorous checking on least-cost design of projects; (ii) need to strengthen 
financial  management  and  transparency  of  financial  statements;  (iii) necessity  of  major 
institutional reforms and operational improvements for the success of a project/program—they 
should be made a precondition for further lending. All these issues have been addressed in the 
last projects for Bangladesh and are the main scope for further reforms in this Program as well. 
 
21.  Delegation of powers from the Government to management of the sector entities and from 
the management to staff is crucial for speedy and efficient decision making. Due to efforts by 
ADB, delegation of power to the sector entities’ boards of directors and management has been 
significantly improved, resulting in speedier decisions on procurement by the newly established 
companies. BPDB and DESA are also restricted by the Government's personnel and wage 
policies; therefore, recruiting and retaining of competent staff and retrenching or dismissing of 
excess or nonperforming staff are inhibited. The situation is being addressed and a beginning has 
been made by RPC, PGCB, and DESCO through market and work-based pay structures. The 
above factors clearly underscore the limited extent of the improvements that can be made to the 
existing power sector entities in their present form. It is therefore essential to (i) create new 
sector entities that are not subject to the organizational limitations of BPDB and DESA, and 
(ii) establish an overall environment of commercialization in the sector.  
 
22.  Fundamental changes in infrastructure sectors take time to implement even in developed 
countries. In developing countries, change is more difficult to implement and, therefore, requires a 
gradual approach. Speeding up reforms is functional only if the change is comprehensive. For 
example, increasing tariffs too rapidly may help the finances of the sector but often undermines 
the objectives of the reforms by penalizing the good consumer if the utilities collect only from a low 
percentage of consumers. Affordability is also a factor. Rapid rises in tariffs can drive up the costs 
of  electricity  so  that  it  becomes  unaffordable  to  poorer  consumers,  whereas  more  gradual 
increases could have allowed time for managing the effects of the increase.

6.  ADB’s Sector Strategy 
27.  ADB recognizes that (i) the substantial external assistance to the sector in the past has 
induced a tendency in the sector agencies to depend on external assistance for their funding; 
(ii) recovery and development must come from within the sector; and (iii) the Government and all 
major aid agencies must realign their individual strategies to emphasize the objective in (ii). In 
consultation with the Government and the other DPs involved in the sector, ADB has developed 
its strategy to improve the power sector in Bangladesh. The strategy consists of (i) changes in the 
business environment through corporatization, commercialization, and increasing private sector 
participation;  (ii) institutional  improvements  in  BPDB  and  DESA;  (iii) creation  of  new  sector 
agencies that could serve as role models for the sector; (iv) enlarging the scope of the PBSs; and 
(v) strengthening the long-term planning and regulatory processes in the sector. The proposed 
Program addresses items (i), (ii), and (iii) of this strategy. Item (iv) is an ongoing process and item 
(v) has partially been addressed through the Power System Master Plan (PSMP), the creation of 
the  Power  Cell,  and  ADB’s  technical  assistance  (TA)  Support  for  an  Energy  Regulatory 
Authority,13 which supports the establishment of the ERC.  
 
28.  In the past, ADB and other DPs extended assistance to discrete power projects in 
Bangladesh on a “policy reform linked assistance”, with substantial policy actions to be taken as 
preconditions for such assistance. This approach enabled the Government and the executing 
agencies (EAs)  to gradually build technical and managerial capacity in the sector. Further, this 
gradual approach has allowed for a smooth transition from the prereform monopolistic model to 
the  postreform  unbundled  model  without  any  major  service  disruption  or  agitation  among 
employees. However, in order to make its interventions more policy oriented and focused, ADB 
decided to concentrate its assistance in the power sector on a limited number of selected entities 
and areas. The first stage reforms have all progressed satisfactorily, creating opportunities to 
widen  and  deepen  the  reforms  as  part  of  a  second  stage.  This  stage  involves  financial 
stabilization of the sector entities created earlier, to enable improved governance of the sector 
through regulatory oversight, and to introduce structured competition and discipline in the sector. It 
is considered that a sector development modality, comprising a policy loan in parallel with an 
investment loan, will be the best instrument to achieve this end. The Program, which will be the 
fifth assistance provided by ADB in support of the reform process, is consistent with ADB's 2003 
Country Assistance Program for Bangladesh.

III.  THE PROPOSED SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Objectives and Scope 
35.  The objective of the Program is to support the Government’s efforts to reform the power 
sector through financial restructuring of two major companies and to prepare for long-term 
sustainability of the sector. Especially, the Program will assist the Government in (i) providing 
support and incentives for sector reform activities such as independent tariff setting, competitive 
dispatch of generation, and functional segregation of sector activities; (ii) promoting the Power 
Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB) and the Dhaka Electric Supply Company (DESCO) as 
commercially viable companies that can access capital markets for at least a part of their future 
capital  needs;  and  (iii) modernizing  and  upgrading  distribution  systems  in  northwest 
Bangladesh. The Project components are linked to the ongoing power sector reforms and will 
(i) expand peak load generation capacity to reduce load shedding, (ii) introduce competition in 
generation, (iii) enhance network reliability, (iv) increase access to electricity services in urban 
areas of northwest of Bangladesh, and (iv) improve efficiency and financial viability including 
further corporatization BPDB’s generation and distribution. The entire exercise is geared to 
improving the power sector’s financial and economic viability over the next  5 years, and to 
enhance sector oversight and governance, thereby providing an assurance of sustained growth 
in the sector. Appendix 4 shows the program framework. 
 
B.  Special Features 
36.  PGCB  will  seek  commercial  cofinancing  through  the  issue  of  Tk2,000 million 
($34.2 million) in long-term tax-free bonds for financing the local currency costs of the NLDC. 
Discussions with commercial banks have already been initiated by ADB in cooperation with the 
management  of  PGCB.  If  the  bonds  are  successfully  raised,  this  will  be  the  first  direct 
commercial borrowing by the public part of the power sector. Utilities cannot be financially self-
sustaining without a long-term bond market. Currently, there is no bond market in Bangladesh, 
and it is the Government’s desire that such a market be developed, since raising capital through 
bonds reduces the requirement of the Government to finance the sector. Since this is a 
developmental effort and also helps the Government’s finances, the Government has indicated 
its willingness to accord tax-free status to this bond issue.

37.  The objective of the Program is to support the Government’s efforts to (i) reform the

D.  The Project Loan 
1.  Objectives 
48.  The objective of the Project is to improve the quality of the electricity supply and this will 
be achieved by (i) improved supply of electricity, reduced load shedding, and balancing the 
national grid regarding supply/demand through construction of about 200 MW peak load power 
generation capacity; (ii) support and incentives for further sector reform activities such as 
independent tariff setting, competitive and optimized dispatch of generation, and functional 
segregation of sector activities, through investment in an NLDC; and (iii) improved access to 
power supply in the relatively underdeveloped northwest region of Bangladesh.  
 
2.  Components and Outputs 
49.  The project loan includes funding for the following components: 
 
Part A -  2  x  100 MW  peaking  power  generation  capacity  at  Siddhirganj,  near 
Dhaka; 
Part B -   the NLDC at Rampura in Dhaka; and 
Part C -   renovation, upgrading, and extension of distribution in Rajshahi, Serajgonj, 
Bogra, Pabna, Rangpur, Dinajpur, Joypurhat, Thakurgaon, Nilphamari, and 
Gaibanda towns in northwest Bangladesh. 
 
50.  Electricity  demand  in  Bangladesh  is  mainly  from  the  residential  sector  and 
consequentially there are sharp peaks in the demand for electricity between 9 am and 1 pm, 
and between 6 pm and 10 pm each day, the evening peak being greater than the morning one. 
At present, these peaks are met either by load shedding or by the use of base load units, which 
are  inappropriate  to  serve  these  types  of  loads  leading  to  higher  fuel  costs  and  greater 
maintenance requirements for the machines. 
 
51.  The Power System Master Plan (PSMP) of 1995 (footnote 4) developed a least-cost 
generation addition plan up to 2015. This plan includes a mix of base load and peak load plants, 
corresponding  to  the  electricity  demand  characteristics  of  Bangladesh.  The  PSMP 
recommended installing 800 MW peaking power plants  by  2005.  As part of the plan, 2 x 
100 MW open-cycle gas turbine generating units are proposed as Part A of the Project to be 
installed within existing Siddhirganj power station complex, which is close to a major load 
center. The proposed plant will meet electricity demand of the country especially in the Dhaka 
area during peak hours, which will address the low voltage problem and improve system 
reliability. The proposed gas turbine plant will be built virtually as a replacement of the old 
inefficient power plants (after dismantling 3 x 10 MW steam plants and the 1 x 50 MW steam 
plant) and there will be no adverse impact on the surrounding area. The technology for these 
units is proven and no major risks are foreseen. The plant is designed to be fired on natural gas 
and requirement will be 3.0 million cubic feet per hour. The fuel will be supplied from the existing 
supply system of Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company.

17 
52.  The plant will comprise: (i) two units of open-cycle gas turbine generating units, each 
having a capacity of 100 to 120 MW; (ii) two sets of unit transformers for two gas turbines; 
(iii) three sets of gas booster compressors for two gas turbines and one standby. The efficiency 
of each gas turbine generating unit will be approximately 33% at site conditions of 35 degrees 
Celsius, 1,013 bars, and 98% relative humidity. 
 
53.  In order to run the country’s power transmission system, which is the responsibility of 
PGCB, in coordination with generation and distribution, it is essential to set up a computer-
controlled NLDC with the modern energy management system (EMS) and supervisory control 
and data acquisition (SCADA) facility, and a fiber optic-based fast communications network. 
This will be able to centrally control the generation, transmission, and distribution economically, 
efficiently, and securely by fixing the instantaneous generation target of a unit through analyzing 
the present scenario of demand and availability of generation. The facilities will support PGCB 
for the most economic dispatch of power generation. 
 
54.  The proposed Part B of the Project is to establish an NLDC at Rampura, Dhaka, 
comprising  EMS  and  SCADA,  to  manage  the  230/132kV  electrical  power  network  and 
associated  substations  and  power  stations.  The  proposed  Project  will  also  include  a 
communications system suitable for transmission of an electrical power system’s data, voice, 
and control commands. The new NLDC will be of sufficient size to accommodate PGCB’s 
requirements in 2007 plus to allow for developments up to 2015. Although this will be the first 
such installation in Bangladesh, BPDB (Chittagong) and DESA have been exposed to a smaller 
supervisory control and data acquisition system built under ADB-funded projects, which is 
operating successfully. However, in order to ensure that the NLDC is designed, engineered, 
constructed,  and  operated  as  per  standards,  the  loan  includes  provision  for  hiring  an 
international  consulting  firm  to  help  PGCB.  Training  of  PGCB  staff  in  operation  and 
maintenance will be provided by the supplier of the NLDC as part of its contract. 
 
55.  Currently, the size of the Bangladesh power system is about 4,700 MW, and by 2007 is 
expected to be about 7,000 MW. The existing central load dispatch center is equipped for 
system monitoring only, using voice communication and is incapable of managing a large power 
system with several generation and distribution entities involved. It cannot take into account the 
economic and commercial parameters and the stability needs. Private generation has already 
started along with that of public sector enterprises and the power system is becoming bigger 
and more complex, both technically and commercially. 
 
56.  Competitive dispatch of generation plants will reduce the cost of generation to the 
system. A modern facility to enable such dispatch will also help in planning for maintenance of 
the various generation units and power system facilities, leading to greater system reliability. 
This is essential if more private sector investments are to be introduced into the generation 
subsector.  
 
57.  Part C of the Project involves upgrading and extending the distribution network in 
northwest Bangladesh by renovating, rehabilitating, and extending the 33 kV, 11 kV, and 0.4 kV 
distribution system in 10 towns. The objective of the Project is to improve system reliability, 
reduce system losses, connect prospective consumers, and strengthen the distribution network. 
This is conventional technology and should not pose any technical risk to BPDB and the 
proposed North-west Zone Power Distribution Company. This support will further boost the 
restructuring of the sector by transferring the operation of the urban distribution from BPDB to a 
newly created company and reduce losses, including all types of commercial losses. It will also 
extend electricity supply to urban households and the commercial sector.

58.  The  main  components  of  Part  C,  distribution,  are:  (i) renovation  of  one  132/33 kV 
substation;  (ii) renovation  of  19  33/11 kV  substations,  (iii) installation  of  11  new  33/11 kV

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Social Aspects 
1.  Social and Poverty Issues 
70.  Since the Program seeks to lower the costs of electricity supply and improve efficiencies 
in operation of the grid, all the electricity consumers of Bangladesh will benefit. The distribution 
upgrade and extension in the northwest part of the country will benefit the urban as well as the 
rural population in the area, both in terms of extension of services to more consumers in urban 
areas as well as in the improvement of quality of supply for both urban and rural areas. The 
program and project components will result in indirect social and  poverty benefits. Improved 
financial management through corporatization of BPDB and DESA and independent tariff rulings 
will  benefit  all  consumer  categories.  Commercialization  will  result  in  improved  corporate 
governance minimizing corruption, reducing losses, and allowing the Government to realize 
savings that could be utilized for social sectors. Construction and operation of the NLDC in 
Rampura will improve load dispatch and systems availability, reduce power outages, and lower 
costs. Dismantling of old, small, inefficient steam turbine power plants and their replacement 
with a peak power generation plant at Siddhirganj will improve the efficiency of the power supply 
to  Dhaka  city  and  will  benefit  several  industries  in  and  around  Dhaka,  including  small 
businesses that cannot afford alternative emergency lighting and power supply. Environmental 
benefits will be realized from the operation of a modern plant with appropriate monitoring 
equipment and management of environmental impacts. 
 
71.  BPDB and the new companies will improve their procedures for public interaction by 
holding regular consultations with different consumer categories. Focus group discussions were 
carried out with different consumer groups to assess the social and poverty impacts. 
 
72.  Improvement and expansion to the distribution network in 10 towns in the northwest 
region will bring considerable benefits in efficiency improvements to all consumers. These towns 
are  district  towns  and  the  lead  local  government  institution  is  the municipality, except for 
Rajshahi,  a  divisional  town  with  a  city  corporation.  Public  sector  institutions  like  schools, 
colleges, and hospitals are operating in all the towns. Some have a university, medical college, 
mental hospital, etc. The population of the towns is about 1.5 million and the total number of 
households is 230,314. The districts are extensions of the rural economy. Some districts are 
leading  vegetable-growing  areas  of  the  country.  Due  to  the  construction  of  the  Jamuna 
multipurpose bridge, the patterns of the economy are changing fast. In most of the towns, a 
gradual expansion of manufacturing and services operations is apparent. These operations are 
generally small, such as light engineering units, flower and rice mills, poultry feeders, bakeries, 
weaving and twisting mills, etc. Cold storage is also gradually increasing. Women work as the 
front line workers in many of the units in all towns. 
 
73.  The power supply situation in all 10 towns is similar. The inadequacy in distribution 
capacity causes frequent power disruptions, particularly in summer. Almost all the towns face 
low voltage problems. The Project aims to enhance the power distribution capacity in the 10 
towns by renovation of existing network as well as installing new facilities. 
 
74.  Improvements are expected in the following areas: (i) all consumers will receive reliable 
and improved quality power supply, (ii) production of commercial and industrial operations will 
be smooth, (iii) low voltage problems will improve, and (iv) replacing old lines with insulated 
ones will improve safety. Electricity will be supplied to any group that requests new connection

22   
or increased supply. Estimated incremental energy supply would be 8,500 GWh during 2007–
2013. 
 
75.  The improvement in the power distribution system will benefit all, including poor, women 
and children. In the commercial category, most of the consumers in the towns utilize between 
100 and 120 kWh, indicating that they operate small businesses and shops. The improvement 
will have a remarkable impact on the growth of cottage industries and enterprises that depend 
on electricity for lighting as well as production. Expansion of employment opportunities and 
poverty reduction is envisaged. Increased income and employment opportunities for the poor 
are expected through a stable power supply leading to stability in manufacturing/services 
processes and increased productivity of the enterprises. Women’s self-employment initiatives, 
leading to additional earning, will be facilitated. 
 
76.  An indirect, but significant positive human development impact is envisaged through 
availability of light for education, improved water supply, diagnostic and health services, etc. 
Children  and  students  will  benefit  from  longer  study  hours,  information  technology-based 
learning,  and  communications  opportunities.  Improved  recreational  facilities  and  better 
municipal services are expected, resulting from improved power supply. Rural areas will also 
have a similar positive impact through improved power supply through the PBSs. Intensity of 
land use under electrically operated irrigation equipment will increase, leading to additional 
employment opportunities. The operational cost for all equipment and lights will be lower than 
those operated by diesel and kerosene. It is envisaged that the power distribution project for the 
10 towns will have a positive impact not only in the project towns but also in the adjoining rural 
areas. In general, rural electrification has far-reaching social and poverty impacts will benefit 
from this Program, since the quality of supply to the rural areas of the northwest will improve as 
a result of the distribution upgrade. 
 
2.  Resettlement 
77.  The NLDC at Rampura and the new peak power generation plant at Siddhirganj do not 
require land acquisition. Both will be set up on existing sites already owned and managed by 
BPDB and PGCB.  
 
78.  Part C of the Project requires a total of 4.5 acres distributed over 10 towns with the 
maximum  land  requirement  at  any  site  not  to  exceed  0.5  acre.  The  land  is  required  for 
construction of 33/11 kV substations. BPDB explored possibilities to minimize land acquisition 
and four towns lowered their original land requirements from one acre to half an acre. BPDB 
has provided written confirmation that government land, free of encumbrances, will be used, 
and that, if needed, private land will be purchased through tender or direct negotiation. There 
will be no compulsory land acquisition. ADB will review land procurement procedures during 
loan review missions. 
 
B.  Financial Aspects 
79.  The financial evaluation of the Program was carried out in real terms using constant 
2003 prices covering the three project loan components independently. Incremental costs and 
benefits were derived by evaluating the financial position of the EAs under with- and without-
project scenarios. All parts show a robust financial internal rate of return (FIRR).  
 
80.  For Part A of the Project, the peak load power plant station, the tariff is computed based 
on current methods of tariff setting for this kind of power plant, demanding a rate of return on

23 
incremental assets of at least 10%. On this basis, the resulting revenue tariff is Tk4.34 (7.36 US 
cents) per kWh, which is normal for a peak load power station. Including the 4% minimum rate 
test, the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) is estimated at 4.63% for this part. 
 
81.  Likewise, for Part B of the Project, the revenues of the NLDC are computed based on an 
expected rate of return on incremental assets of at least 10%, which is the current method of 
setting the wheeling charges for the transmission grid. In achieving a return of at least 10%, an 
increase of Tk0.027 per kWh in transmission charges during 2008, the first revenue generation 
year, has been assumed. Including the 4% minimum rate test, the WACC is estimated at 4.4% 
for this part. 
 
82.  For Part C of the Project, renovation and upgrading of the distribution in the northwest of 
Bangladesh, the FIRR is estimated at 26%. The WACC, including the 4% minimum rate test, is 
4.79%. 
 
83.  Sensitivity analyses for the three components found comfortable switching values for 
increases in capital costs and energy input prices, reduction in benefits, as well as a worst-case 
scenario of a combination of these. From a financial point of view, all three project components 
are  robust  and  comfortably  above  the  respective  WACC.  Detailed  financial  analyses  are 
presented in Appendix 10. 
 
C.  Economic Aspects 
84.  All components of the Program will result in increased and efficient supply of electricity 
to consumers. For this Program, the economic analysis has been carried out for the investment 
portion (i) peak load power plant, (ii) NLDC, and (iii) the distribution network in 10 towns, only. 
As the program component is financial restructuring of DESCO, PGCB, and other power sector 
entities, it has not been considered in the economic analysis. 
 
85.  The base case economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the peak load power plant was 
estimated at 20.2%, for the NLDC, 24.0%, and for the distribution network in 10 towns, 38.7%. 
The combined EIRR for all three components was estimated at 29.1%. 
 
86.  Sensitivity analyses for the three components found comfortable switching values for 
increases in capital costs and energy input prices, reduction in benefits, change in curvature 
factors, as well as a worst-case scenario for a combination of all these aspects. From an 
economic point of view, the Program is robust. Detailed economic analysis is presented in 
Appendix 11. 
 
D.  Environmental Aspects 
87.  The  reforms  as  part  of  the  policy  component  are  mainly  focused  on  financial 
restructuring aspects, and therefore no potential environmental impact of the policy loan exists. 
However,  there  is  an  opportunity  to  establish  an  institutional  arrangement  for  handling 
environmental and safety issues within the corporatized BPDB. The environmental consultant 
will be hired to identify the tasks and responsibilities of the unit and conduct training to prepare 
the power plant to operate in an environmentally acceptable manner. 
 
88.  The  investment  component,  which  includes  dismantling  of  old,  inefficient,  power 
generating  units  at  Siddhirganj  is  not  expected  to  generate  any  significant environmental 
impacts. During the construction stage, the dismantling and disposal of old machineries that

24   
have been used for a long time have to be carried out in accordance with good practices. The 
following mitigation measures need to be adopted: (i) all the old machinery will be washed, to 
clean it of oil content inside the project area, and the waste water has to meet effluent standards 
before disposing of it into a water body; (ii) the waste oil will only be sold to parties authorized 
by the Government for recycling, or reuse of waste oil; (iii) only clean scrap will be sold to the 
market. Although the operation of the new power plant will contribute to improving Dhaka’s air 
quality,  it  is  necessary  to  undertake  environmental  monitoring  in  accordance  with  the 
Bangladesh Environmental Conservation Act and Rules, to ensure that all emissions, effluents, 
and noise will meet the existing environmental standards of Bangladesh. 
 
89.  The expansion of the distribution system is not expected to generate any significant 
impact, either during construction or operation. However, the location of the substations will 
need to be selected carefully to avoid noise disturbance to neighboring schools, clinics, etc. 
Furthermore, it is also required that only transformers free of Poly Chlorinated Biphenyl (PCB) 
will be installed and that all cooling equipment should be free of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). 
 
E.  Risks 
90.  The success of the Program partially depends on the successful creation of the new 
power  generation  company  and  the  North-west  Zone  Power  Distribution  Company,  and 
recruitment of their management. The sector has comprehensive experience in setting up new 
companies  under  the  Companies  Act  from  previous  projects.  Furthermore,  based  on  the 
ongoing successful restructuring of the sector, advertised managerial positions have been very 
attractive in the market. Hence, there have been a lot of applications from highly qualified 
professionals for these positions.  
 
91.  One major constraint might be the Government’s compliance with the settlement of its 
outstanding dues to the sector and the recruitment of competent regulators for the ERC.

1.  The power sector in Bangladesh is organized under the Ministry of Energy and Mineral 
Resources. The Government, through the ministry, wholly owns and supervises the Bangladesh 
Power Development Board (BPDB), the Dhaka Electricity Supply Authority (DESA), and the Rural 
Electrification Board (REB), which are its three executing agencies in the sector. Until fiscal year 
(FY) 1998, BPDB was responsible for all generation and most of the transmission in the country, 
and also for distribution in district towns, municipalities, and some rural areas, while DESA was 
responsible for distribution in the greater Dhaka area, including the capital city. The distribution of 
electricity in most of the rural areas of Bangladesh is the responsibility of the 67 rural electric 
cooperatives or palli bidyut samities (PBSs), which are organized, initially funded, and monitored 
by REB. As part of the sector reform process, new public sector entities such as the Power Grid 
Company of Bangladesh Ltd. (PGCB) and the Dhaka Electric Supply Company Ltd. (DESCO) 
as  well  as  private  sector  independent  power  producers  (IPPs)  such  as  the  Rural  Power 
Company Ltd. (RPC),1 the Meghnaghat AES Power Company Ltd.,2 and the Haripur AES Power 
Company Ltd. have been constituted. Over the next few years, these companies will own and 
operate a substantial part of the power sector’s assets. The distribution subsector has also seen 
a major rationalization of distribution territory between DESA and the PBSs. The Government, 
BPDB, and REB have taken steps to involve the private sector by (i) adopting a private power 
generation policy in October 1996, (ii) adopting a small power generation policy in 1998 to 
encourage distributed generation, and (iii) awarding contracts for about 1,800 megawatts (MW) 
of generating capacity on a build-own-operate (BOO) basis.

calculated for a period of 17 years including 2 years of construction with a life span of 15 
years with no residual value. Based on ruling tariff-setting principles, demanding a return on 
incremental investments of at least 10.0%, the revenue comes out at Tk4.34 (7.36 US cents)

power because of facilitated instant dispatch of the most economical power. However, the 
overall economic benefits in cost savings through more efficient dispatch will not result in 
any additional revenue to the executing agency, but justifies an increase of the wheeling 
charges  for  transmission  to  cover  the  additional  investment  and  operational  costs.  In

C.  Description of the Environment 
 
1.  Project area involved in and affected by the replacement of old  
power plant with the new gas power plant 
 
5.  The project area is located in Siddhirgonj Power Plant Complex of Naryanngonj District 
and situated 1.5 km east of Dhaka–Chittagong Highway. This power plant complex is also part 
of Siddhirgonj Industrial Area. The site is flat, and it was land filled by riverbed dredging that was 
done in the early 1970s. The existing steam power plant is one of the power plants located in 
this complex, where there are two other gas and steam power plants inside this power plant 
complex. There is no residential area near to the complex. No cultural artifacts or historical 
remains are in the vicinity (at radius 5 km). There is no environmentally sensitive area, however, 
the complex is located about 1 km from Shitalaxma river. The river is the important source of 
water for this industrial complex. 
   
2.  Project Area Involved In and Affected by Distribution Lines 
 
6.  The project area will spread all over northwest zone of Bangladesh. It involves 10 towns 
and all of them are capital districts, therefore, it is characterized by a small-town type of 
ecosystem. There is no environmentally sensitive area involved in this subproject, and no 
cultural artifacts or historical remains are affected by the Project. All the substations (existing 
and new) are not located nearby the residential area, and none of them is located near to any 
social infrastructures (e.g., clinic, school).  
 
D.  Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
1.  Replacement of the Old Steam Power Generation Plant with the New Gas 
Power Plant (open-cycle turbine)  
 
7.  There is no significant impact expected due to the site of the Project, since the project is 
located within the power plant complex belonging to BPDB. The existing steam power plant, 
which was established in the early 1970s, is generating 50 MW of power, which is being used to 
serve Dhaka’s demand.  
 
8.  This investment component will not include any development of transmission line, since 
adequate transmission systems already are in place. Therefore, the main feature of the project 
activities as part of construction work is dismantling of the existing building and machinery. The 
scrap machinery has an economic value, however, this machinery has been used for a long 
time, and therefore some of it has become corrosive and most of it contains lubrication oil as 
well as transformer oil. To mitigate any environmental impact associated with the used scrap, 
the following mitigation measures will be adopted: (i) all the old machinery will be washed, to 
clean its oil content, inside the project area. Wastewater from washing the machinery will be 
disposed of in the river after trapping its oil, and the oil contained in its wastewater should not 
exceed the Bangladesh Effluent Standard (10 mg/l); (ii) the waste oil will only be disposed or 
sold to the parties that are authorized by the Government to treat oil waste; and (iii) only clean 
scrap will be sold to the market. The disposal from dismantling the building will be used to fill up 
the lower area inside the power plant complex.  
 
9.  The  environmental  impacts  associated  with  the  construction  of  new  building  and 
mobilizing the new machinery are negligible and will only locally affect the project area, in fact 
only within the power plant complex. There will be no dumping of construction materials outside

2.  Expansion of Distribution Line 
  
11.  The  screening  of  potential  impacts  identifies  that  there  will  be  no  significant 
environmental impact due to sitting of these distribution line and substation, because all these 
subprojects will be carried out in the town area and mostly in the existing facilities and along the 
roads. The environmental impacts associated with the construction stage will mostly involve 
traffic disturbance. To minimize this impact, a clear traffic sign will be placed in the construction 
area and if necessary traffic will be rerouted. Good practices during the installation of cable or 
distribution line will be adopted and will be included in the bidding document. Therefore, it is 
clear that the impacts associated with the rehabilitation of distribution line will be minimal and 
the mitigation measures will be manageable.  
 
12.  It is predicted also that there will be an environmental impact associated with the 
rehabilitation of the substation particularly related with the disposal of damaged equipment (e.g., 
transformers, conductors). Unused transformers and equipment that contain Poly Chlorinated 
Biphenyl (PCB) will be collected and cleaned prior to selling them or disposing of them on the 
market. The wastewater from cleaning of the equipment will be disposed of after treating them 
as required by the Government. A permit to sell, dispose, and use materials containing PCBs 
will be processed by the Central Environmental Authority.  
 
13.  To avoid future environmental problems, it is also recommended that the Project will only 
use (i) PCB-free transformers and conductors; and (ii) chlorofluorocarbon (CFC)-free cooling 
system equipment. To avoid noise problems, it is recommended to locate the transformers at a 
reasonable distance so that noise level from the fence will not exceed 55 decibels during the 
day and 45 decibels during the night. It is clear that the proposed mitigation measures are 
practical and manageable and all of these will be included in the loan covenants.  
 
E.  Institutional Requirement and Environmental Monitoring Program 
 
  1.  Institutional Framework and Responsibility 
 
14.  Implementation  of  mitigation  measures  during  the  construction  stage  will  be  the 
responsibility  of  the  contractor.  The  construction  supervisors  from  the  Bangladesh  Power 
Development Board (BPDB) will be responsible in preparing contract documentation so that the 
bidding documents, bills of quantity, and other contractual obligations of the contractor clearly 
identify environmental responsibilities and describe penalties for noncompliance. BPDB will also 
monitor the waste oil as part of the effluent disposed outside the project area. BPDB will ensure

BPDB is responsible for implementing overall mitigation measures and the monitoring plan, 
which includes collaboration with other agencies (e.g., Department of Explosives for testing

rerouting traffic during the construction stage, and Bangladesh Road and Transport Agency for 
monitoring the movement of buses and auto rickshaws outside Dhaka).  
 
2.  Environmental Monitoring and Management Plan 
 
15.  The IEE has identified the generic monitoring and management program, which will be 
part of the mitigation on the adverse impacts, which mostly will become responsibility of BPDB. 
Therefore, it is recommended that an environmental and safety unit be established within the 
power plant organization.  
 
16.   Environmental  monitoring  to  ensure  environmental  mitigation  measures  during  the 
construction stage will be carried out by BPDB. While the environmental monitoring to maintain 
environmental quality (e.g., effluent emission and other potential pollution such as disposing of 
hazardous and toxic units including oil, as well as noise) during construction and operation will 
be  carried  out  by  Siddhirganj  Power  Company  in  accordance  with  the  Bangladesh 
Environmental  Conservation  Act  1995  and  Bangladesh  Conservation  Rules  1997  to  meet 
existing government-prescribed environmental quality standards. 
 
F.  Findings and Recommendations 
 
17.  The IEE study shows that environmental impacts associated with this proposed Project 
are manageable and can be mitigated. While the positive impact particularly in improving air 
quality will lead to reducing the threat on public health. In addition, none of environmentally 
sensitive  areas  will  be  involved  in  this  Project.  Therefore,  a  full  environmental  impact 
assessment to analyze further impacts is not required. However, the Project is categorized as a 
“red category project” in accordance with Bangladesh’s Environmental Preservation Rules 1997. 
Therefore, any construction works for this Project only can be done after the Department of 
Environment issues an environmental clearance.  
 
G.  Conclusion 
 
18.  The Project will contribute to improving air quality. The overall IEE finding is that the 
Project will not cause significant environmental problems and that the potential adverse impacts 
are manageable. However, monitoring should be continued.
